Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Why do skunks smell so bad? It all comes down to chemistry. By the way, this video will include slow motion
footage of skunk anuses. So, be warned. I’m Anna Rothschild, and this is Gross Science. There are a number of species of skunk in
the world, but the most iconic has to be the striped skunk. That’s the one that looks like Pepe Le Pew—it’s
all black, typically with one white line that usually splits into two on its back. And it can be found all over the United States
as well as northern Mexico and southern Canada. Its latin name is Mephitis mephitis, which
appropriately enough means something like foul stench or noxious vapor. Obviously, that’s because the most defining
character of skunks is their defensive spray, which can cause watery eyes, nausea, and leave
you smelling terrible. The chemical makeup of the spray is different
depending on the species, but all of them contain special types of compounds called
“thiols.” Thiols, also known as “mercaptans,” are
a type of chemical group made up of a sulfur and hydrogen atom bonded together. And they typically smell really strongly. There are actually three different thiols
in striped skunks spray, and two of those are the main contributors to the awful odor. But three other molecules in the spray are
what are called “thioacetates.” Those compounds don’t have a strong scent,
but they can easily become thiols when they’re exposed to water. And that might explain why a pet that gets
sprayed may start to smell skunky again after a bath. Now, skunk musk is produced by anal scent
glands—which actually, lots of mammals have, though most aren’t quite this exciting. When a skunk sprays, nipple-like protrusions
called papillae come out of the anus and squirt the musk at the target. The bad news is they can squirt a distance
of about 10 feet, and are uncannily good at hitting their mark. The good news is that skunks really don’t
want to spray unless they have to, and adults usually give warning signals beforehand. Striped skunks will hiss, stomp, and raise
their tails before spraying. And spotted skunks will even do a handstand. But, what should you do on the off-chance
that you wind up covered in musk? Well, definitely don’t use tomato juice—that’s
just a myth. Instead, use something that converts the thiol
into a different type of compound. Some scientists suggest using a mixture of
dilute hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, and a little liquid soap, which will oxidize the
thiol and turn it into a sulfonic acid. But be careful, because it could dye your
hair or pet fur. Anyway, despite their terrible reputation,
some skunks have actually been domesticated, and people say they make really cute and affectionate
pets. But if you do want a pet skunk, make sure
you know how to take care of it and get one from a breeder. Grabbing one from the woods is not at all
nice for the skunk. And it would probably let you know that by
squirting you with an anal gland full of noxious musk. Ew.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where is the primary habitat of the iconic striped skunk?
Options: A. North America, B. South America, C. Central America, D. Europe, E. Asia
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason why skunks smell so bad? Options: A. Their unique fur color, B. The chemical makeup of their defensive spray, C. Their diet consisting mainly of strong-smelling foods, D. Their ability to produce a lot of sweat Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which type of chemical group is responsible for the strong smell in skunk spray? Options: A. Aldehydes, B. Thiols, C. Esters, D. Ketones Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the name of the species of skunk that is commonly found in the United States, northern Mexico, and southern Canada? Options: A. Mephitis mephitis, B. Pepe Le Pew, C. Striped skunk, D. Domesticated skunk Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the purpose of the warning signals given by skunks before spraying? Options: A. To attract more skunks to the area, B. To scare away potential threats, C. To signal the start of mating season, D. To indicate the location of food Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the recommended method for removing skunk musk from a pet? Options: A. Using tomato juice, B. Using a mixture of dilute hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, and liquid soap, C. Washing the pet with regular soap and water, D. Using a strong-smelling detergent Correct Option: B
Question 6: What type of compounds are produced by the anal scent glands of skunks? Options: A. Thiols, B. Thioacetates, C. Both thiols and thioacetates, D. Neither thiols nor thioacetates Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why do thioacetates in skunk spray not have a strong smell? Options: A. Because they are not volatile, B. Because they are not reactive, C. Because they can easily become thiols when exposed to water, D. Because they are not present in skunk spray Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the purpose of the papillae in the anal scent glands of skunks? Options: A. To produce the musk, B. To store the musk, C. To squirt the musk at the target, D. To regulate the amount of musk produced Correct Option: C
Question 9: Why is it not recommended to grab a skunk from the woods to keep as a pet? Options: A. Because it may be injured, B. Because it may be diseased, C. Because it may spray its musk as a defense mechanism, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the name of the video series in which the transcript is presented? Options: A. Gross Science, B. Skunk Science, C. Animal Facts, D. Science Explained Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

Although Question 3 does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, its content and options are the most similar. The ground truth MCQ asks about the primary habitat of the iconic striped skunk, while Question 3 asks about the name of the species of skunk that is commonly found in the United States, northern Mexico, and southern Canada. However, the options in Question 3, particularly option A (Mephitis mephitis) and option C (Striped skunk), provide information about the striped skunk's habitat, which is mentioned in the transcript as the United States, northern Mexico, and southern Canada.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 3.

footage of skunk anuses. So, be warned. I’m Anna Rothschild, and this is Gross Science. There are a number of species of skunk in

all black, typically with one white line that usually splits into two on its back. And it can be found all over the United States

character of skunks is their defensive spray, which can cause watery eyes, nausea, and leave

depending on the species, but all of them contain special types of compounds called
“thiols.” Thiols, also known as “mercaptans,” are
a type of chemical group made up of a sulfur and hydrogen atom bonded together. And they typically smell really strongly. There are actually three different thiols
in striped skunks spray, and two of those are the main contributors to the awful odor. But three other molecules in the spray are
what are called “thioacetates.” Those compounds don’t have a strong scent,
but they can easily become thiols when they’re exposed to water. And that might explain why a pet that gets

that you wind up covered in musk? Well, definitely don’t use tomato juice—that’s
just a myth. Instead, use something that converts the thiol
into a different type of compound. Some scientists suggest using a mixture of
dilute hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, and a little liquid soap, which will oxidize the
thiol and turn it into a sulfonic acid. But be careful, because it could dye your
hair or pet fur. Anyway, despite their terrible reputation,

pets. But if you do want a pet skunk, make sure
you know how to take care of it and get one from a breeder. Grabbing one from the woods is not at all
nice for the skunk. And it would probably let you know that by
squirting you with an anal gland full of noxious musk. Ew.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Why do skunks smell so bad? It all comes down to chemistry. By the way, this video will include slow motion
footage of skunk anuses. So, be warned. I’m Anna Rothschild, and this is Gross Science. There are a number of species of skunk in
the world, but the most iconic has to be the striped skunk. That’s the one that looks like Pepe Le Pew—it’s
all black, typically with one white line that usually splits into two on its back. And it can be found all over the United States
as well as northern Mexico and southern Canada. Its latin name is Mephitis mephitis, which
appropriately enough means something like foul stench or noxious vapor. Obviously, that’s because the most defining
character of skunks is their defensive spray, which can cause watery eyes, nausea, and leave
you smelling terrible. The chemical makeup of the spray is different
depending on the species, but all of them contain special types of compounds called
“thiols.” Thiols, also known as “mercaptans,” are
a type of chemical group made up of a sulfur and hydrogen atom bonded together. And they typically smell really strongly. There are actually three different thiols
in striped skunks spray, and two of those are the main contributors to the awful odor. But three other molecules in the spray are
what are called “thioacetates.” Those compounds don’t have a strong scent,
but they can easily become thiols when they’re exposed to water. And that might explain why a pet that gets
sprayed may start to smell skunky again after a bath. Now, skunk musk is produced by anal scent
glands—which actually, lots of mammals have, though most aren’t quite this exciting. When a skunk sprays, nipple-like protrusions
called papillae come out of the anus and squirt the musk at the target. The bad news is they can squirt a distance
of about 10 feet, and are uncannily good at hitting their mark. The good news is that skunks really don’t
want to spray unless they have to, and adults usually give warning signals beforehand. Striped skunks will hiss, stomp, and raise
their tails before spraying. And spotted skunks will even do a handstand. But, what should you do on the off-chance
that you wind up covered in musk? Well, definitely don’t use tomato juice—that’s
just a myth. Instead, use something that converts the thiol
into a different type of compound. Some scientists suggest using a mixture of
dilute hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, and a little liquid soap, which will oxidize the
thiol and turn it into a sulfonic acid. But be careful, because it could dye your
hair or pet fur. Anyway, despite their terrible reputation,
some skunks have actually been domesticated, and people say they make really cute and affectionate
pets. But if you do want a pet skunk, make sure
you know how to take care of it and get one from a breeder. Grabbing one from the woods is not at all
nice for the skunk. And it would probably let you know that by
squirting you with an anal gland full of noxious musk. Ew.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Mercaptans or thiols are made up of hydrogen and ______________________ bonded together which results in a horrible odor.
Options: A. oxygen, B. carbon, C. thorium, D. sulfur
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 4

**Transcript**:
Why do skunks smell so bad? It all comes down to chemistry. By the way, this video will include slow motion
footage of skunk anuses. So, be warned. I’m Anna Rothschild, and this is Gross Science. There are a number of species of skunk in
the world, but the most iconic has to be the striped skunk. That’s the one that looks like Pepe Le Pew—it’s

in striped skunks spray, and two of those are the main contributors to the awful odor. But three other molecules in the spray are

but they can easily become thiols when they’re exposed to water. And that might explain why a pet that gets

nice for the skunk. And it would probably let you know that by
squirting you with an anal gland full of noxious musk. Ew.

Correct Option: A

thiol and turn it into a sulfonic acid. But be careful, because it could dye your
hair or pet fur. Anyway, despite their terrible reputation,
some skunks have actually been domesticated, and people say they make really cute and affectionate
pets. But if you do want a pet skunk, make sure
you know how to take care of it and get one from a breeder. Grabbing one from the woods is not at all
nice for the skunk. And it would probably let you know that by
squirting you with an anal gland full of noxious musk. Ew.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: You have been sprayed by a striped skunk! How can you get rid of the thiols?
Options: A. grape juice, B. water content of the soil, C. tomato juice, D. a mix of hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, liquid soap
Correct Option: D

Question 2: Which type of chemical group is responsible for the strong smell in skunk spray? Options: A. Aldehydes, B. Thiols, C. Esters, D. Ketones Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Pretty much as long as humans have looked
up at the night sky, we’ve been studying astronomy. In all this time, we’ve learned so much
about the universe beyond our Solar System, and have found lots of exoplanets orbiting
other stars. But there’s a lot that scientists still
don’t know. In fact, three relatively recent exoplanet
discoveries are completely baffling researchers because, according to what we know about astronomy,
they shouldn’t exist! The first of these planets is called Kepler-78b, which was discovered using data from NASA’s
Kepler space telescope, and orbits a star about 400 light years away
from Earth. Based on changes in its star’s light, astronomers
calculated that Kepler-78b’s radius is about 1.2 times the radius of Earth and it’s around 1.7 times as massive as
the Earth. This means it also has a similar density to
the Earth, so the researchers think its composition is
similar, too, with lots of rock and iron. But that’s where the similarities stop. Kepler-78b is about 100 times closer to its
star than the Earth is to the Sun, and its surface temperatures might even get
up to 3,100 Kelvin. Basically, it’s kind of like Earth … if
Earth was a blazing inferno. This planet’s super close orbit to its host
star means that a year only lasts 8.5 hours. And scientists don’t understand how Kepler-78b
even exists, because it doesn’t fit any of the current
theories of planetary formation it’s just too close to its star. See, when Kepler-78b was first forming from the gas and dust-filled protoplanetary
disk, its host star was even larger. So if the planet was orbiting where it is
now, it would’ve been inside its star, which
is... impossible. Another option is that it formed farther away
and migrated closer, but scientists think that’s pretty unlikely, since it probably would’ve kept going and
plummeted into the star. As of now, it’s a mystery. The main thing we do know about Kepler-78b is that it’ll probably only be around for
another three billion years or so. It’ll move closer and closer to its host
star, until the gravity eventually tears it apart. Our next mysterious planet is called Kepler-10c, which was also detected using data from the
Kepler space telescope, and is about 560 light years away from us. It’s radius isn’t all that special. It’s only about 2.3 times the radius of
the Earth. And initially, because of its size, scientists predicted that Kepler-10c would
have a thick, gaseous atmosphere, making it like a mini-Neptune. Instead, they found a planet with a mass that
might be between 14-17 times the Earth’s, which suggests that it’s a really dense
rocky planet without much of an atmosphere. A mass that large is basically unheard of
in a planet that size, which is why astronomers dubbed it a mega-Earth. Which, y’know, sounds pretty cool. Based on our current understanding of planets, one this massive without an atmosphere shouldn’t
even exist. Theoretically, it would’ve grabbed a bunch
of nearby lighter elements with its huge gravitational force as the star
system was forming, and turned into a gas giant like Jupiter. But it probably never even had an atmosphere, because if it did at some point, it would’ve
held onto it. So, right now, scientists are just left with
another giant rock in space that they can’t really explain. Last but not least, we have a gas giant named
HD 106906 b, which is 11 times as massive as Jupiter, and discovered using data from the Hubble
Space Telescope and the Magellan telescope in Chile. This planet orbits a really young star 300
light years away from Earth. The system is only 13 million years old. But that’s not what makes it weird. See, HD 106906 b orbits its star at a distance
of 650 astronomical units. That’s more than 20 times the average distance
between the Sun and Neptune. A planet that far away from its host star shouldn’t have had enough gaseous and rocky
materials to grow that huge, especially in such a relatively short period
of time. But, somehow, it exists. Some researchers think it might have formed inside the dust-filled debris disk surrounding
its host star, and got kicked out later, but they’re still
not sure. A recent study seems to support this idea, suggesting that the planet might have even
captured some of that dusty material, and might be surrounded by a ring or shroud. But that’s just one hypothesis and, until
astronomers get more data, the planet is still an enigma. These three planets are just a drop in the
bucket that is our universe, and we still have so much to learn. It’s really the strangest discoveries that
make astronomy so cool. Every time we start to think we understand
how certain things work, like planetary formation, amazing surprises
get thrown our way. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow
Space, and a special thank you to all of our patrons
on Patreon. If you’d like to support more videos like
this one, please go to Patreon.com/SciShow. And don’t forget to go to YouTube.com/SciShowSpace
and subscribe!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Kepler-78b is so close to its star that a year only lasts...
Options: A. 23 seconds, B. 8.5 hours, C. 2 weeks, D. 56 days
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 3: What is unique about the surface temperature of Kepler-78b? Options: A. It's very cold, B. It's similar to the Earth's, C. It might get up to 3,100 Kelvin, D. It's not mentioned in the transcript Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why is Kepler-78b's existence puzzling to scientists? Options: A. It's too close to its star, B. It's too far away from its star, C. It has a thick atmosphere, D. It has a thin atmosphere Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the predicted lifespan of Kepler-78b? Options: A. A few billion years, B. A few hundred million years, C. A few thousand years, D. It's not mentioned in the transcript Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the name of the second mysterious exoplanet mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. Kepler-78b, B. Kepler-10c, C. HD 106906 b, D. None of the above Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is unusual about the mass of Kepler-10c? Options: A. It's very small, B. It's very large, C. It's similar to the Earth's, D. It's not mentioned in the transcript Correct Option: B

other stars. But there’s a lot that scientists still
don’t know. In fact, three relatively recent exoplanet

they shouldn’t exist! The first of these planets is called Kepler-78b, which was discovered using data from NASA’s
Kepler space telescope, and orbits a star about 400 light years away
from Earth. Based on changes in its star’s light, astronomers
calculated that Kepler-78b’s radius is about 1.2 times the radius of Earth and it’s around 1.7 times as massive as

the Earth, so the researchers think its composition is

star than the Earth is to the Sun, and its surface temperatures might even get
up to 3,100 Kelvin. Basically, it’s kind of like Earth … if
Earth was a blazing inferno. This planet’s super close orbit to its host
star means that a year only lasts 8.5 hours. And scientists don’t understand how Kepler-78b
even exists, because it doesn’t fit any of the current
theories of planetary formation it’s just too close to its star. See, when Kepler-78b was first forming from the gas and dust-filled protoplanetary
disk, its host star was even larger. So if the planet was orbiting where it is
now, it would’ve been inside its star, which
is... impossible. Another option is that it formed farther away

plummeted into the star. As of now, it’s a mystery. The main thing we do know about Kepler-78b is that it’ll probably only be around for

star, until the gravity eventually tears it apart. Our next mysterious planet is called Kepler-10c, which was also detected using data from the
Kepler space telescope, and is about 560 light years away from us. It’s radius isn’t all that special. It’s only about 2.3 times the radius of
the Earth. And initially, because of its size, scientists predicted that Kepler-10c would
have a thick, gaseous atmosphere, making it like a mini-Neptune. Instead, they found a planet with a mass that
might be between 14-17 times the Earth’s, which suggests that it’s a really dense
rocky planet without much of an atmosphere. A mass that large is basically unheard of

even exist. Theoretically, it would’ve grabbed a bunch
of nearby lighter elements with its huge gravitational force as the star

Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What's so great about the Great Lakes? They're known as America's inland seas. The North American Great Lakes Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, and Superior are so massive
that they border eight states and contain 23 quadrillion
liters of water. That's enough to cover the land area
of the contiguous United States three meters deep. These vast bodies of water span forest, grassland, and wetland habitats, supporting a region that's home to over
3,500 species. But how did such a vast and unique
geological feature come to be? The story begins near the end
of the last ice age over 10,000 years ago, a time when the climate was warming and the glaciers that cloaked the Earth's
surface began their slow retreat. These immense ice sheets carved out
a series of basins. Those basins filled with water
as the ice began to melt, creating the world's largest area
of freshwater lakes. Over time, channels developed between
these basins, and water began to flow in
an ongoing exchange that persists to this day. In fact, today,
the interconnected Great Lakes contain almost 20% of the world's supply
of fresh surface water. The water's journey begins in
the far north of Lake Superior, which is the deepest, coldest,
and clearest of the lakes, containing half the system's water. Lake Superior sinks to depths
of 406 meters, creating a unique and diverse ecosystem
that includes more that 80 fish species. A given drop of water spends on average
200 years in this lake before flowing into Lake Michigan
or Lake Huron. Linked by the Straits of Mackinac,
these two lakes are technically one. To the west lies Lake Michigan, the third largest of the lakes
by surface area. Water slowly moves through
its cul-de-sac shape and encounters the world's largest
freshwater dunes, many wildlife species, and unique fossilized coral. To the east is Lake Huron,
which has the longest shoreline. It's sparsely populated,
but heavily forested, including 7,000-year-old petrified trees. Below them, water continues to flow
southeastwards from Lake Huron into Lake Erie. This lake's status as the warmest
and shallowest of the five has ensured an abundance of animal life,
including millions of migrating birds. Finally, the water reaches its last stop
by dramatically plunging more than 50 meters down
the thundering Niagara Falls into Lake Ontario, the smallest lake
by surface area. From there, some of this well-traveled
water enters the St. Lawrence River, eventually reaching the Atlantic Ocean. In addition to being a natural wonder, the perpetually flowing Great Lakes
bring us multiple benefits. They provide natural water filtration, flood control, and nutrients cycling. By moving water across
more than 3,200 kilometers, the Great Lakes also provide drinking
water for upward of 40 million people and 212 billion liters a day
for the industries and farms that line their banks. But our dependence on the system is
having a range of negative impacts, too. The Great Lakes coastal habitats are being
degraded and increasingly populated, exposing the once pristine waters to industrial, urban,
and agricultural pollutants. Because less than 1% of the water
leaves the Lake's system annually, decades-old pollutants still lurk
in its waters. Humans have also inadvertently introduced more than 100 non-native
and invasive species into the lakes, such as zebra and quagga mussels,
and sea lampreys that have decimated some indigenous
fish populations. On a larger scale, climate change
is causing the waters to warm, thus reducing water levels and changing
the distribution of aquatic life. Luckily, in recent years, governments have
started to recognize the immense value of this natural resource. Partnerships between the United States and
Canada are underway to reduce pollution, protect coastal habitats, and halt the spread of invasive species. Protecting something as massive
as the Great Lakes system will require the collaboration
of many organizations, but the effort is critical if we can preserve the wonder
of this flowing inland sea.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where are the Great Lakes located?
Options: A. Within the United States and Canada, B. Within the United States only, C. Within Canada only, D. In Central America
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the total volume of water in the Great Lakes? Options: A. 10 quadrillion liters, B. 20 quadrillion liters, C. 23 quadrillion liters, D. 30 quadrillion liters Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which of the following is a benefit of the Great Lakes? Options: A. Natural water filtration, flood control, and nutrients cycling, B. Industrial, urban, and agricultural pollutants, C. Invasive species and climate change, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 3: How long does a given drop of water spend in Lake Superior before flowing into Lake Michigan or Lake Huron? Options: A. 100 years, B. 200 years, C. 500 years, D. 1000 years Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the strait that links Lake Michigan and Lake Huron? Options: A. Straits of Mackinac, B. Straits of Detroit, C. Straits of Niagara, D. Straits of Superior Correct Option: A
Question 5: Which of the following is a negative impact of human dependence on the Great Lakes? Options: A. Natural water filtration and flood control, B. Industrial, urban, and agricultural pollutants, C. Invasive species and climate change, D. None of the above Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the river that the Great Lakes water eventually flows into? Options: A. St. Lawrence River, B. Niagara River, C. Detroit River, D. Lake Erie Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the approximate surface area of the contiguous United States that the Great Lakes could cover three meters deep? Options: A. 1 million square kilometers, B. 2 million square kilometers, C. 3 million square kilometers, D. 4 million square kilometers Correct Option: C
Question 8: Which of the following is a benefit of the Great Lakes for industries and farms? Options: A. Drinking water for 40 million people, B. 212 billion liters of water per day, C. Natural water filtration and flood control, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the name of the lake that is the warmest and shallowest of the five? Options: A. Lake Superior, B. Lake Michigan, C. Lake Huron, D. Lake Erie Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the approximate depth of Lake Superior? Options: A. 200 meters, B. 300 meters, C. 400 meters, D. 500 meters Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the overall intent and geographical context, I would say that Question 7 is the most similar generated MCQ.

Although Question 7 does not directly ask about the location of the Great Lakes, it does provide information about the surface area that the Great Lakes could cover, which is related to their geographical location and scale.

However, if I had to choose a question that is more closely related to the location of the Great Lakes, I would say that none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. But if I really had to choose, I would say that Question 4 is the most similar generated MCQ, as it mentions the Straits of Mackinac, which is a geographical feature that connects two of the Great Lakes and implies their location.

But again, I want to emphasize that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4 (with the caveat that it's not a direct match)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What's so great about the Great Lakes? They're known as America's inland seas. The North American Great Lakes Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, and Superior are so massive
that they border eight states and contain 23 quadrillion
liters of water. That's enough to cover the land area
of the contiguous United States three meters deep. These vast bodies of water span forest, grassland, and wetland habitats, supporting a region that's home to over
3,500 species. But how did such a vast and unique
geological feature come to be? The story begins near the end
of the last ice age over 10,000 years ago, a time when the climate was warming and the glaciers that cloaked the Earth's
surface began their slow retreat. These immense ice sheets carved out
a series of basins. Those basins filled with water
as the ice began to melt, creating the world's largest area
of freshwater lakes. Over time, channels developed between
these basins, and water began to flow in
an ongoing exchange that persists to this day. In fact, today,
the interconnected Great Lakes contain almost 20% of the world's supply
of fresh surface water. The water's journey begins in
the far north of Lake Superior, which is the deepest, coldest,
and clearest of the lakes, containing half the system's water. Lake Superior sinks to depths
of 406 meters, creating a unique and diverse ecosystem
that includes more that 80 fish species. A given drop of water spends on average
200 years in this lake before flowing into Lake Michigan
or Lake Huron. Linked by the Straits of Mackinac,
these two lakes are technically one. To the west lies Lake Michigan, the third largest of the lakes
by surface area. Water slowly moves through
its cul-de-sac shape and encounters the world's largest
freshwater dunes, many wildlife species, and unique fossilized coral. To the east is Lake Huron,
which has the longest shoreline. It's sparsely populated,
but heavily forested, including 7,000-year-old petrified trees. Below them, water continues to flow
southeastwards from Lake Huron into Lake Erie. This lake's status as the warmest
and shallowest of the five has ensured an abundance of animal life,
including millions of migrating birds. Finally, the water reaches its last stop
by dramatically plunging more than 50 meters down
the thundering Niagara Falls into Lake Ontario, the smallest lake
by surface area. From there, some of this well-traveled
water enters the St. Lawrence River, eventually reaching the Atlantic Ocean. In addition to being a natural wonder, the perpetually flowing Great Lakes
bring us multiple benefits. They provide natural water filtration, flood control, and nutrients cycling. By moving water across
more than 3,200 kilometers, the Great Lakes also provide drinking
water for upward of 40 million people and 212 billion liters a day
for the industries and farms that line their banks. But our dependence on the system is
having a range of negative impacts, too. The Great Lakes coastal habitats are being
degraded and increasingly populated, exposing the once pristine waters to industrial, urban,
and agricultural pollutants. Because less than 1% of the water
leaves the Lake's system annually, decades-old pollutants still lurk
in its waters. Humans have also inadvertently introduced more than 100 non-native
and invasive species into the lakes, such as zebra and quagga mussels,
and sea lampreys that have decimated some indigenous
fish populations. On a larger scale, climate change
is causing the waters to warm, thus reducing water levels and changing
the distribution of aquatic life. Luckily, in recent years, governments have
started to recognize the immense value of this natural resource. Partnerships between the United States and
Canada are underway to reduce pollution, protect coastal habitats, and halt the spread of invasive species. Protecting something as massive
as the Great Lakes system will require the collaboration
of many organizations, but the effort is critical if we can preserve the wonder
of this flowing inland sea.

Question: Which of the Great Lakes is the largest, containing half of all the water in the system?
Options: A. Lake Huron, B. Lake Ontario, C. Lake Michigan, D. Lake Superior
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:

that they border eight states and contain 23 quadrillion
liters of water. That's enough to cover the land area

fish populations. On a larger scale, climate change
is causing the waters to warm, thus reducing water levels and changing
the distribution of aquatic life. Luckily, in recent years, governments have
started to recognize the immense value of this natural resource. Partnerships between the United States and
Canada are underway to reduce pollution, protect coastal habitats, and halt the spread of invasive species. Protecting something as massive
as the Great Lakes system will require the collaboration
of many organizations, but the effort is critical if we can preserve the wonder
of this flowing inland sea.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The benefits provided by the Great Lakes system include:
Options: A. International shipping and transportation, B. A high rate of biodiversity, C. Potable water for human activity, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the total volume of water in the Great Lakes? Options: A. 10 quadrillion liters, B. 20 quadrillion liters, C. 23 quadrillion liters, D. 30 quadrillion liters Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which of the following is a benefit of the Great Lakes? Options: A. Natural water filtration, flood control, and nutrients cycling, B. Industrial, urban, and agricultural pollutants, C. Invasive species and climate change, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 3: How long does a given drop of water spend in Lake Superior before flowing into Lake Michigan or Lake Huron? Options: A. 100 years, B. 200 years, C. 500 years, D. 1000 years Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the strait that links Lake Michigan and Lake Huron? Options: A. Straits of Mackinac, B. Straits of Detroit, C. Straits of Niagara, D. Straits of Superior Correct Option: A
Question 5: Which of the following is a negative impact of human dependence on the Great Lakes? Options: A. Natural water filtration and flood control, B. Industrial, urban, and agricultural pollutants, C. Invasive species and climate change, D. None of the above Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the name of the river that the Great Lakes water eventually flows into? Options: A. St. Lawrence River, B. Niagara River, C. Detroit River, D. Lake Erie Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the approximate surface area of the contiguous United States that the Great Lakes could cover three meters deep? Options: A. 1 million square kilometers, B. 2 million square kilometers, C. 3 million square kilometers, D. 4 million square kilometers Correct Option: C
Question 8: Which of the following is a benefit of the Great Lakes for industries and farms? Options: A. Drinking water for 40 million people, B. 212 billion liters of water per day, C. Natural water filtration and flood control, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the name of the lake that is the warmest and shallowest of the five? Options: A. Lake Superior, B. Lake Michigan, C. Lake Huron, D. Lake Erie Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the approximate depth of Lake Superior? Options: A. 200 meters, B. 300 meters, C. 400 meters, D. 500 meters Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

Although the options in Question 8 do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, the intent of the question is similar. Both questions ask about the benefits provided by the Great Lakes system. Question 8 mentions specific benefits for industries and farms, as well as the general population, which aligns with the ground truth MCQ's option C, "Potable water for human activity." 

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of options and content. But Question 8 is the closest match in terms of question intent and the benefits mentioned.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Perfumers can learn to distinguish
individual odors in a fragrance made of hundreds of scents. Tea experts have been known to sniff out not just the location 
where a tea was from, but the season of harvest
and whether it was planted by a plum tree. And the New York City Transit Authority once had an employee responsible
only for sniffing out gas leaks in the subway system. Can just anyone learn to smell
with the sensitivity of those experts? For most of us, what we smell
is largely involuntary, whether it's garbage behind a restaurant, the shampoo of the woman leaving
an elevator as you enter, or a bakery's fresh-made bread. With a few million olfactory receptors
in our noses, we clearly don't lack the ability
to smell well. We just might not always pay close
enough attention. That's a shame because we may be
missing opportunities to make strong emotional connections. Smells are powerfully linked to emotions and can awaken memories of places
we've long ago left and people we've loved. But fortunately, it is possible
to train our brains to smell better. For example, Helen Keller was able
to recognize a person's work, and in her words, distinguish the carpenter
from the iron worker, the artist from the mason or the chemist, by a simple inhale. Follow these steps and you too can
change the way the world smells to you. First, stick your nose in it. Some animals that are known
to be great smellers, like dogs who can sniff out explosives and pigs who can 
find truffles underground, put their noses right at the place
they want to smell. Human noses, meanwhile, are casting
around in the middle of the air, giving us an anatomical disadvantage. So bring your nose close to the world
around you. The ground, surfaces, objects, the food in your hand. Get close to your dog, your partner, the book you're reading. Not only will your nose be closer
to the odor source, but the warmth of your breath
will make odors easier to smell. Second, sniff like you mean it. Smelling actually happens way up near
the bridge of our noses in a postage stamp-sized square
of tissue called the olfactory epithelium. When we sniff, odor molecules are sucked
up into our nostrils until they hit this tissue where they combine to our olfactory,
or scent, receptors. When we inhale normally,
only a little air makes it there. But one or two solid sharp sniffs will ensure that more air gets to
your smell receptors. After just a few more sniffs, the receptors, which are best at
noticing new smells, turn off temporarily. So you can give your nose a rest
and sniff again later. Finally, dwell on the smell. Most smells pass by us 
with little attention, but simply noticing what you're smelling and by trying to describe it, name it,
and locate its source, you can expand your vocabulary of smells. When an odor molecule binds
to a scent receptor, it sends an electrical signal
from the sensory neurons to our brain's olfactory bulbs. The signal then continues to other
areas of the brain, where it's integrated with taste, memory, or emotional information before registering to us as a smell. FMRI research shows that the extra
time spent focusing on scent changes the brain of experienced smellers. For them, perceiving and imagining odors
becomes more automatic than for non-experts. To get started yourself, take ingredients
from your kitchen: spices, vanilla, or fruit, but never anything toxic. Close your eyes and have someone
bring them under your nose. Sniff and try to name the source. Over time, you'll begin to appreciate
nuances in familiar odors and recognize characteristics of new
and unusual smells. The perfumer has practiced these steps
enough to become an artist of odor, but even if you never pursue smelling
to that degree, the spectacular result 
of an unspectacular action will change how you sense 
and experience your days.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: For most people, what we tend to smell is:
Options: A. Voluntary, B. Involuntary, C. An odor from someone we know, D. An odor that we only smelled previously
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is unique about the way human noses operate compared to some animals that are known to be great smellers? Options: A. Human noses are better at detecting a wide range of odors., B. Human noses are anatomically designed to cast around in the middle of the air., C. Human noses are less sensitive to smells than those of animals., D. Human noses are able to detect smells from a great distance. Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is one way to train our brains to smell better? Options: A. By ignoring our sense of smell., B. By focusing on a specific smell for a long time., C. By paying close enough attention to the world around us., D. By not using our noses at all. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the name of the tissue in the nose where odor molecules combine with olfactory receptors? Options: A. Olfactory epithelium, B. Nasal cavity, C. Sinus, D. Trachea Correct Option: A
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is the result of the brain's increased activity when we focus on scent? Options: A. It becomes less automatic for experienced smellers., B. It becomes more automatic for experienced smellers., C. It has no effect on experienced smellers., D. It becomes less effective for non-experts. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the first step in the process of training our brains to smell better? Options: A. Sniffing like you mean it., B. Dwell on the smell., C. Stick your nose in it., D. Focus on the source of the smell. Correct Option: C
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is one way to ensure that more air gets to the smell receptors in the nose? Options: A. By inhaling normally., B. By taking a few solid, sharp sniffs., C. By holding your breath., D. By exhaling slowly. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the purpose of the olfactory epithelium in the nose? Options: A. To detect light., B. To detect sounds., C. To detect smells., D. To detect tastes. Correct Option: C
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the result of an unspectacular action of focusing on scent? Options: A. It has no effect on how we sense and experience our days., B. It changes how we sense and experience our days., C. It makes us less sensitive to smells., D. It makes us more sensitive to sounds. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the process by which odor molecules are detected in the nose? Options: A. By binding to taste receptors., B. By binding to olfactory receptors., C. By binding to smell receptors., D. By binding to sight receptors. Correct Option: B
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is one way to begin training our brains to smell better? Options: A. By ignoring our sense of smell., B. By focusing on a specific smell for a long time., C. By taking ingredients from your kitchen and sniffing them., D. By not using our noses at all. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

Although the wording of the questions is different, the intent and content of Question 2 align with the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks about what people tend to smell, and the correct answer is "involuntary." Question 2 asks about how to train our brains to smell better, and the correct answer is "by paying close enough attention to the world around us." This implies that most people do not pay close attention to smells, which is why what we smell is largely involuntary.

However, a more similar question would be one that directly asks about the nature of how people tend to smell. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs directly ask this question. But among the given options, Question 2 is the closest match in terms of intent and content.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2

Options: A. Humans have anatomically disadvantageous nose placement and getting close is a way to overcome it, B. The warmth of your breath will make odors easier to smell, C. Touching what you are smelling will increase your detection of its odor, D. A and B, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Perfumers can learn to distinguish
individual odors in a fragrance made of hundreds of scents. Tea experts have been known to sniff out not just the location 
where a tea was from, but the season of harvest
and whether it was planted by a plum tree. And the New York City Transit Authority once had an employee responsible
only for sniffing out gas leaks in the subway system. Can just anyone learn to smell
with the sensitivity of those experts? For most of us, what we smell
is largely involuntary, whether it's garbage behind a restaurant, the shampoo of the woman leaving
an elevator as you enter, or a bakery's fresh-made bread. With a few million olfactory receptors
in our noses, we clearly don't lack the ability
to smell well. We just might not always pay close
enough attention. That's a shame because we may be
missing opportunities to make strong emotional connections. Smells are powerfully linked to emotions and can awaken memories of places
we've long ago left and people we've loved. But fortunately, it is possible
to train our brains to smell better. For example, Helen Keller was able
to recognize a person's work, and in her words, distinguish the carpenter
from the iron worker, the artist from the mason or the chemist, by a simple inhale. Follow these steps and you too can
change the way the world smells to you. First, stick your nose in it. Some animals that are known
to be great smellers, like dogs who can sniff out explosives and pigs who can 
find truffles underground, put their noses right at the place
they want to smell. Human noses, meanwhile, are casting
around in the middle of the air, giving us an anatomical disadvantage. So bring your nose close to the world
around you. The ground, surfaces, objects, the food in your hand. Get close to your dog, your partner, the book you're reading. Not only will your nose be closer
to the odor source, but the warmth of your breath
will make odors easier to smell. Second, sniff like you mean it. Smelling actually happens way up near
the bridge of our noses in a postage stamp-sized square
of tissue called the olfactory epithelium. When we sniff, odor molecules are sucked
up into our nostrils until they hit this tissue where they combine to our olfactory,
or scent, receptors. When we inhale normally,
only a little air makes it there. But one or two solid sharp sniffs will ensure that more air gets to
your smell receptors. After just a few more sniffs, the receptors, which are best at
noticing new smells, turn off temporarily. So you can give your nose a rest
and sniff again later. Finally, dwell on the smell. Most smells pass by us 
with little attention, but simply noticing what you're smelling and by trying to describe it, name it,
and locate its source, you can expand your vocabulary of smells. When an odor molecule binds
to a scent receptor, it sends an electrical signal
from the sensory neurons to our brain's olfactory bulbs. The signal then continues to other
areas of the brain, where it's integrated with taste, memory, or emotional information before registering to us as a smell. FMRI research shows that the extra
time spent focusing on scent changes the brain of experienced smellers. For them, perceiving and imagining odors
becomes more automatic than for non-experts. To get started yourself, take ingredients
from your kitchen: spices, vanilla, or fruit, but never anything toxic. Close your eyes and have someone
bring them under your nose. Sniff and try to name the source. Over time, you'll begin to appreciate
nuances in familiar odors and recognize characteristics of new
and unusual smells. The perfumer has practiced these steps
enough to become an artist of odor, but even if you never pursue smelling
to that degree, the spectacular result 
of an unspectacular action will change how you sense 
and experience your days.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Olfactory receptors:
Options: A. Detect new smells best, B. Detect familiar odors best, C. Never shut off, D. Are found near the tip of your nose
Correct Option: A

However, a more relevant question would be one that directly addresses the characteristics of olfactory receptors, which is not present among the generated MCQs.

If I had to choose a question that is somewhat related to the characteristics of olfactory receptors, I would choose Question 6, as it discusses how to ensure that more air gets to the smell receptors in the nose, which is related to the functioning of olfactory receptors.

However, if I had to choose a question that is somewhat related to the given options of the ground truth MCQ, I would choose Question 9, as it discusses the binding of odor molecules to olfactory receptors, which is related to the functioning of olfactory receptors.

In summary, while there isn't an exact match, I would choose Question 7 as the closest match in terms of content, but I would also consider Questions 6 and 9 as somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you look at cars from the 1970s and cars
from the 1990s, there’s really one big difference in their designs. The ones from the 70s are boxy, and the ones
from the 90s are curvy. For some car models, you can even tell the
exact year when that change happened. Just look at this commercial for the Buick
LeSabre, showing the 1991 model — and then the 1992 model. See the curves? Let’s watch that again. ‘91 is boxy, sharp edges. ‘92? Smooth and round. Since then, cars have become curvier and curvier. So how did this happen? When manufacturers started making curvy cars
in the 90s, it wasn’t a totally new concept. Back in the 1930s, streamliners like this Chrysler
Airflow used this sleek design to reduce wind resistance. But as the 50s and 60s rolled around, American
streamliners stopped selling well — they were outsold by bigger, boxier cars. Gas prices were on fairly steady decline at
this point, so streamlining for fuel efficiency was less of a concern. Well into the 1970s, just about every car
made in America had sharp edges and very few curves. They were basically designed as a series of
three boxes — the hood, the cabin, and the trunk. That model worked really well in the US market. But in Europe, fuel was always more expensive. In the 60s, a gallon of gas in France cost
a whopping 73.1 cents while it was just 31 cents in the US. So European designers started experimenting
with more aerodynamic designs to help cars move more easily so they’d waste less gas. Automakers like Porsche, BMW, Audi, Mercedes-Benz
— they all started rolling out car models that had curved exteriors. Eventually American automakers started to
copy the European aerodynamic look to try to attract upscale consumers. The mass market was a different picture. In Europe, a designer named Uwe Bahnsen was
the first person to push for a curved design for the average driver, and he did that with
the 1982 Ford Sierra. It was curvier than any car in its class at
the time. But critics just laughed at it. And it didn't sell very well at first. It was nicknamed the “jelly mould” because
of how much it looked like the kind of circular shape you’d make JELL-O with. But one of the designers from that European
Ford design team — this guy, Jack Telnack — took over the US design team in 1980. American gas prices at this point were skyrocketing
due to conflict in the middle east. So Telnack brought wind tunnel testing into
the design process. He first did that with the 1983 Ford Thunderbird. But the real breakthrough came a few years
later: "The result was the groundbreaking 1986 Ford
Taurus." It might not look that groundbreaking now,
but this style was revolutionary at the time. It was a mass market car with curvy edges
— and people liked it. “Taurus! Now a North American car with a shape and
a feel we’ve never seen before… Taurus for us!” They used it in RoboCop as the car of the
future. The sales basically saved Ford, which had
really been struggling at the time, and it inspired a whole wave of copycat curvy cars. And streamlining became even more popular
because manufacturers were facing new fuel economy regulations in the US. Starting in 1978, the average fuel efficiency
of each manufacturer’s passenger cars had to meet higher and higher levels. According to one Ford designer, aerodynamic
design was a much more affordable way to boost efficiency than doing engineering work under
the hood. The rise of computer modelling in the 80s
also made it easier for car makers to design and manufacture curved lines. All these years later, the influence on today’s
cars is pretty clear. Even the models that we criticize for being
ridiculously boxy these days — like the Scion xB — are actually really round. And if our modern day sci fi movies have anything
to say about it, that won’t be changing anytime soon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to this video, what was the main reason cars went from being 'curvy' to 'boxy' in the early 1960s?
Options: A. curvy cars were considered 'un-American', B. America was in a race to land on the moon, and boxy cars were considered futuristic, C. fuel prices were dropping
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main difference in the designs of cars from the 1970s and the 1990s? Options: A. The 1970s cars were smaller than the 1990s cars., B. The 1970s cars were boxy, while the 1990s cars were curvy., C. The 1970s cars had more advanced technology than the 1990s cars., D. The 1970s cars were more expensive than the 1990s cars. Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which car model is credited with pushing for a curved design for the average driver in Europe? Options: A. Ford Sierra, B. Buick LeSabre, C. Chrysler Airflow, D. Scion xB Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the nickname given to the Ford Sierra due to its design? Options: A. "Jelly mould", B. "Streamliner", C. "Curvy car", D. "Boxy beast" Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the breakthrough that came a few years after the 1983 Ford Thunderbird? Options: A. The introduction of wind tunnel testing, B. The development of the 1986 Ford Taurus, C. The creation of the Scion xB, D. The release of the Buick LeSabre Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what was the main reason American streamliners stopped selling well in the 1950s and 1960s? Options: A. Gas prices were on the rise, B. Gas prices were on a steady decline, C. American consumers preferred boxier cars, D. European designers were more influential Correct Option: B
Question 6: Which of the following is an example of a European automaker that started rolling out car models with curved exteriors in the 1960s? Options: A. Ford, B. BMW, C. Mercedes-Benz, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What was the result of the 1986 Ford Taurus? Options: A. It was a commercial failure, B. It was a groundbreaking car with curvy edges, C. It was a mass market car that sold poorly, D. It was a car with a boxy design Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what was a more affordable way for manufacturers to boost efficiency than doing engineering work under the hood? Options: A. Aerodynamic design, B. Wind tunnel testing, C. Computer modelling, D. Both A and C Correct Option: D
Question 9: Which of the following is an example of a car that was criticized for being ridiculously boxy? Options: A. Scion xB, B. Ford Sierra, C. Buick LeSabre, D. Chrysler Airflow Correct Option: A
Question 10: What was the influence of the 1986 Ford Taurus on the automotive industry? Options: A. It led to a decline in sales of curvy cars, B. It inspired a wave of copycat curvy cars, C. It led to a shift towards boxier designs, D. It had no significant impact Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the reason for a shift in car design, specifically why American streamliners stopped selling well or why cars went from being 'curvy' to 'boxy'. The correct options for both questions also mention fuel prices, with the ground truth MCQ stating that fuel prices were dropping and Question 5 stating that gas prices were on a steady decline. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Some of the world's most recognizable
symbols exist to sell products, others to steer traffic or advance political causes. But there's one whose main purpose
is to help people. You may know it as the wheelchair symbol,
or a sign for people with disabilities, but its formal title as maintained
by the ISO is the International Symbol of Access. But despite its familiarity, many people are unclear as to what 
the symbol actually means, which has a lot to do with the symbol
itself and the way it came about. In 1968, the International Commission
on Technology and Accessibility held a design contest. They were looking for a symbol that would be readily identifiable 
from a reasonable distance, self-descriptive, simple, practical, and couldn't be confused
with existing signage. The winning design, 
which didn't have a head, was created by a Danish designer
named Susanne Koefed. The addition of a head a year later
gave it a more human form, and within ten years, it was endorsed by both the United Nations
and the ISO. With minimal cost and minimal fuss,
a global icon was born. There have been a few tweaks
over the decades. The Graphic Artists Guild added more
rounded, human-like features, and in 2012, the Accessible Icon Project
produced a more dynamic version. But what does it really represent? What's its purpose? Put simply, it's a sign to identify where
there are accessible facilities. The strength of such an internationally
recognized image is that wherever you travel, you don't need to speak the language
or have in-depth cultural knowledge. If you require an accessible toilet,
the sign shows the way. But the confusion comes 
from the term accessibility and what that actually means. Many people assume that because
the symbol depicts a wheelchair, that accessible facilities are meant
only for people who use wheelchairs, or those, at the very least,
who have a visible physical condition. But accessibility is a broad concept that applies to many, 
many different conditions. That includes people with autism, visual impairments, and autoimmune diseases, like lupus, which can cause 
pain and fatigue, along with many other conditions. In fact, the World Health 
Organization estimates that there are approximately
1 billion people who experience some form of disability, which means that this group is very
likely to include yourself, or a family member, a classmate, a friend, or a work colleague. And people who use wheelchairs only
make up about 65 million, or 15% of the total. The vast majority 
have non-visible disabilities. Accessible parking spaces, facilities,
and entrances are designed with 
that entire group in mind. So it's easy to see why in recent years
people have begun to raise questions about whether the symbol is really
appropriate for what it's meant to do. And it's not just about accuracy. It's common for people 
to become indignant, sometimes abusive, when they see people without visible
disabilities using accessible facilities. The symbol is unfortunately creating
widespread issues for the very people and families
it's meant to help. The recent redesigns have attempted
with some success to acknowledge concerns 
over the current symbol. But some think that a complete redesign
is in order. It's a difficult task, though. How do you replace a symbol 
that's familiar the world over? And what do you replace it with?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was missing from the original design of the International Symbol of Access?
Options: A. A wheel, B. A head, C. A person, D. A leg
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the formal title of the International Symbol of Access, as maintained by the ISO? Options: A. The Wheelchair Symbol, B. The International Symbol of Access, C. The Disability Sign, D. The Accessible Facilities Sign, A. To create a symbol that would be readily identifiable from a reasonable distance, B. To create a symbol that would be simple and practical, C. To create a symbol that would be self-descriptive, D. All of the above, A. It became less recognizable, B. It became more abstract, C. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Some of the world's most recognizable
symbols exist to sell products, others to steer traffic or advance political causes. But there's one whose main purpose
is to help people. You may know it as the wheelchair symbol,
or a sign for people with disabilities, but its formal title as maintained
by the ISO is the International Symbol of Access. But despite its familiarity, many people are unclear as to what 
the symbol actually means, which has a lot to do with the symbol
itself and the way it came about. In 1968, the International Commission
on Technology and Accessibility held a design contest. They were looking for a symbol that would be readily identifiable 
from a reasonable distance, self-descriptive, simple, practical, and couldn't be confused
with existing signage. The winning design, 
which didn't have a head, was created by a Danish designer
named Susanne Koefed. The addition of a head a year later
gave it a more human form, and within ten years, it was endorsed by both the United Nations
and the ISO. With minimal cost and minimal fuss,
a global icon was born. There have been a few tweaks
over the decades. The Graphic Artists Guild added more
rounded, human-like features, and in 2012, the Accessible Icon Project
produced a more dynamic version. But what does it really represent? What's its purpose? Put simply, it's a sign to identify where
there are accessible facilities. The strength of such an internationally
recognized image is that wherever you travel, you don't need to speak the language
or have in-depth cultural knowledge. If you require an accessible toilet,
the sign shows the way. But the confusion comes 
from the term accessibility and what that actually means. Many people assume that because
the symbol depicts a wheelchair, that accessible facilities are meant
only for people who use wheelchairs, or those, at the very least,
who have a visible physical condition. But accessibility is a broad concept that applies to many, 
many different conditions. That includes people with autism, visual impairments, and autoimmune diseases, like lupus, which can cause 
pain and fatigue, along with many other conditions. In fact, the World Health 
Organization estimates that there are approximately
1 billion people who experience some form of disability, which means that this group is very
likely to include yourself, or a family member, a classmate, a friend, or a work colleague. And people who use wheelchairs only
make up about 65 million, or 15% of the total. The vast majority 
have non-visible disabilities. Accessible parking spaces, facilities,
and entrances are designed with 
that entire group in mind. So it's easy to see why in recent years
people have begun to raise questions about whether the symbol is really
appropriate for what it's meant to do. And it's not just about accuracy. It's common for people 
to become indignant, sometimes abusive, when they see people without visible
disabilities using accessible facilities. The symbol is unfortunately creating
widespread issues for the very people and families
it's meant to help. The recent redesigns have attempted
with some success to acknowledge concerns 
over the current symbol. But some think that a complete redesign
is in order. It's a difficult task, though. How do you replace a symbol 
that's familiar the world over? And what do you replace it with?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many people across the globe does the World Health Organization estimate are living with some type of disability?
Options: A. One hundred thousand, B. One million, C. Fifty million, D. One billion
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the formal title of the International Symbol of Access, as maintained by the ISO? Options: A. The Wheelchair Symbol, B. The International Symbol of Access, C. The Disability Sign, D. The Accessible Facilities Sign, A. To create a symbol that would be readily identifiable from a reasonable distance, B. To create a symbol that would be simple and practical, C. To create a symbol that would be self-descriptive, D. All of the above, A. It became less recognizable, B. It became more abstract, C. It gave it a more human form, D. It made it more complicated, A. A sign of wealth and prosperity, B. A sign of danger and warning, C. A sign to identify where there are accessible facilities, D. A sign of love and friendship, A. 50%, B. 65%, C. 75%, D. 90%, A. 500 million, B. 1 billion, C. 2 billion, D. 3 billion, A. Because it is not easily recognizable, B. Because it is not widely used, C. Because it is creating widespread issues for the very people and families it's meant to help, D. Because it is not accurate, A. Finding a new designer, B. Coming up with a new design, C. symbols exist to sell products, others to steer traffic or advance political causes. But there's one whose main purpose
is to help people. You may know it as the wheelchair symbol,
or a sign for people with disabilities, but its formal title as maintained
by the ISO is the International Symbol of Access. But despite its familiarity, many people are unclear as to what 
the symbol actually means, which has a lot to do with the symbol
itself and the way it came about. In 1968, the International Commission
on Technology and Accessibility held a design contest. They were looking for a symbol that would be readily identifiable 
from a reasonable distance, self-descriptive, simple, practical, and couldn't be confused
with existing signage. The winning design, 
which didn't have a head, was created by a Danish designer
named Susanne Koefed. The addition of a head a year later
gave it a more human form, and within ten years, it was endorsed by both the United Nations
and the ISO. With minimal cost and minimal fuss,
a global icon was born. There have been a few tweaks
over the decades. The Graphic Artists Guild added more
rounded, human-like features, and in 2012, the Accessible Icon Project
produced a more dynamic version. But what does it really represent? What's its purpose? Put simply, it's a sign to identify where
there are accessible facilities. The strength of such an internationally
recognized image is that wherever you travel, you don't need to speak the language
or have in-depth cultural knowledge. If you require an accessible toilet,
the sign shows the way. But the confusion comes 
from the term accessibility and what that actually means. Many people assume that because
the symbol depicts a wheelchair, that accessible facilities are meant
only for people who use wheelchairs, or those, at the very least,
who have a visible physical condition. But accessibility is a broad concept that applies to many, 
many different conditions. That includes people with autism, visual impairments, and autoimmune diseases, like lupus, which can cause 
pain and fatigue, along with many other conditions. In fact, the World Health 
Organization estimates that there are approximately
1 billion people who experience some form of disability, which means that this group is very
likely to include yourself, or a family member, a classmate, a friend, or a work colleague. And people who use wheelchairs only
make up about 65 million, or 15% of the total. The vast majority 
have non-visible disabilities. Accessible parking spaces, facilities,
and entrances are designed with 
that entire group in mind. So it's easy to see why in recent years
people have begun to raise questions about whether the symbol is really
appropriate for what it's meant to do. And it's not just about accuracy. It's common for people 
to become indignant, sometimes abusive, when they see people without visible
disabilities using accessible facilities. The symbol is unfortunately creating
widespread issues for the very people and families
it's meant to help. The recent redesigns have attempted
with some success to acknowledge concerns 
over the current symbol. But some think that a complete redesign
is in order. It's a difficult task, though. How do you replace a symbol 
that's familiar the world over? And what do you replace it with?
